section.title: Polite requests
section.sectiontitle: We use Can I ... Could I (possibly) ... Is it all right/okay if I ... Do you think I could ... + verb? to ask if we can do things.
section.text1a: Could I possibly borrow your pen? Certainly.
section.text2a: Is it all right if I use the scanner? Well, I'm afraid I need it at the moment.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use Do you mind if I + verb? to ask for permission. This means Is it a problem if I …?
section.text3a: Do you mind if I smoke? No, not at all.
section.text4a: Do you mind if I sit here? I'm afraid someone's already here.

section.title: Polite requests
section.sectiontitle: We use Can you ... Could you (possibly) ... Do you think you could … Will you ... Would you ... + verb? to ask other people to do things.
section.text2a: Do you think you could check this letter?  Sorry, but I don't have time now.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use Do you mind ... and Would you mind ... + -ing? for requests. This means Is it a problem for you to ...?
section.text3a: Do you mind helping me with this bag? No, not at all.
section.text4a: Would you mind lending me £20? Well, the problem is I've only got £5 myself.

section.title: Polite requests
section.sectiontitle: We use Do you mind if I … Do/Would you mind + -ing … Could I/you (possibly) … Do you think I/you could … when we want to sound particularly polite.
section.text1a: Do you think I could possibly use your mobile?
section.sectiontitle2: Could/Would you … are a little more polite than Can/Will you …? However, in all these questions the intonation is more important than the words.
section.text4a: Would you hold this for a moment, please?
